fields.name: Cover Letter Tips
fields.description: Tips and advice for writing effective cover letters

fields.title: How to Write a Cover Letter That Gets You Noticed
fields.summary: Learn the essential elements of a standout cover letter that will help you get noticed by hiring managers and land more interviews.
fields.content:
A well-crafted cover letter can be the difference between getting an interview and having your application ignored. In this comprehensive guide, we'll walk you through the process of writing a cover letter that effectively showcases your skills and experience.

The Purpose of a Cover Letter

Before diving into the writing process, it's important to understand what a cover letter is meant to accomplish. A cover letter serves several key purposes:

  • It introduces you to the hiring manager
  • It explains why you're interested in the position and company
  • It highlights your most relevant qualifications
  • It demonstrates your communication skills
  • It shows that you've put effort into your application

Cover Letter Structure

A well-structured cover letter typically includes the following components:

1. Header and Greeting

Include your contact information at the top, followed by the date and the employer's contact information. Address the letter to a specific person whenever possible. Research the company to find the hiring manager's name, or call the company to ask.

2. Opening Paragraph

Your opening paragraph should grab attention and clearly state the position you're applying for. Mention how you learned about the opportunity and briefly explain why you're interested in the role and company.

3. Body Paragraphs (1-2)

The body of your cover letter should highlight your most relevant qualifications and achievements. Rather than repeating your resume, focus on specific examples that demonstrate your skills and how they align with the job requirements. Use metrics and specific results whenever possible.

4. Closing Paragraph

In your closing paragraph, express enthusiasm for the opportunity to interview and discuss how you can contribute to the company. Include a call to action, such as stating that you'll follow up in a week if you haven't heard back.

Tips for Writing an Effective Cover Letter

Research the Company

Before writing your cover letter, research the company thoroughly. Understand their mission, values, culture, and recent achievements. This will help you tailor your letter to show how you're a good fit for their specific needs and environment.

Customize for Each Application

Never use a generic cover letter. Customize each letter for the specific job and company. Reference the job description and use similar language to show that you understand what they're looking for.

Show, Don't Tell

Instead of simply stating that you have certain skills, provide specific examples that demonstrate those skills in action. For example, rather than saying you're a 'problem-solver,' describe a specific problem you solved and the positive outcome.

Keep It Concise

Your cover letter should be no more than one page with 3-4 paragraphs. Be clear and concise, focusing on your most relevant qualifications and achievements.

Use Professional Language

Maintain a professional tone throughout your cover letter. Avoid using slang, contractions, or overly casual language. However, you should still let your personality shine through in a professional way.

Proofread Carefully

Errors in your cover letter can immediately disqualify you from consideration. Proofread multiple times, use spell check, and ask someone else to review your letter before submitting.

Common Cover Letter Mistakes to Avoid

  • Being too generic: Failing to customize your letter for the specific job and company
  • Rehashing your resume: Simply repeating the information in your resume without adding new insights
  • Focusing on what you want: Emphasizing what you hope to gain rather than what you can contribute
  • Including irrelevant information: Adding details that don't relate to the job requirements
  • Being too modest or too boastful: Either downplaying your achievements or exaggerating them
  • Using a template without customization: Submitting a template letter without personalizing it

Cover Letter Examples

While it's important to write your own cover letter, looking at examples can provide inspiration and guidance. Check out our cover letter examples for various industries and positions to see how effective cover letters are structured.

Final Thoughts

A well-written cover letter is an opportunity to showcase your qualifications and personality in a way that a resume alone cannot. By following these guidelines and putting in the effort to customize each letter, you'll significantly increase your chances of landing an interview and ultimately securing the job you want.

Remember, your cover letter is often your first impression with a potential employer. Make it count by being authentic, specific, and professional.

fields.title: 5 Cover Letter Templates for Different Career Situations
fields.summary: Discover cover letter templates tailored for different career situations, including career changes, entry-level positions, and experienced professionals.
fields.content:
Different career situations call for different approaches to your cover letter. Whether you're a recent graduate, changing careers, or a seasoned professional, this guide provides templates and strategies for crafting the perfect cover letter for your specific situation.

1. Entry-Level Position Cover Letter

When you're just starting your career, you may worry about lacking experience. However, an effective entry-level cover letter focuses on transferable skills, education, internships, and enthusiasm.

Template Structure:

  • Opening: Express enthusiasm for the position and company. Mention how you learned about the opportunity.
  • Education: Highlight relevant coursework, projects, and academic achievements.
  • Experience: Discuss internships, volunteer work, part-time jobs, or extracurricular activities that demonstrate relevant skills.
  • Skills: Emphasize transferable skills such as communication, teamwork, and problem-solving.
  • Closing: Show enthusiasm for contributing to the company and learning in the role.

2. Career Change Cover Letter

When transitioning to a new industry or role, your cover letter needs to connect your previous experience to your new career path.

Template Structure:

  • Opening: Clearly state your intention to change careers and your interest in the specific role.
  • Transferable Skills: Highlight skills from your previous career that apply to the new position.
  • Relevant Experience: Discuss any experience, even if volunteer or educational, related to your new field.
  • Why the Change: Briefly explain your motivation for changing careers, focusing on positive reasons.
  • Learning Commitment: Express your commitment to learning and growing in the new field.

3. Experienced Professional Cover Letter

With significant experience in your field, your cover letter should highlight your achievements and demonstrate how your expertise will benefit the company.

Template Structure:

  • Opening: Reference your years of experience and specific expertise relevant to the position.
  • Key Achievements: Highlight 2-3 significant accomplishments with measurable results.
  • Industry Knowledge: Demonstrate your understanding of industry trends and challenges.
  • Leadership: If applicable, discuss your experience leading teams or projects.
  • Closing: Express interest in discussing how your experience can help the company achieve its goals.

4. Referral Cover Letter

When someone in the company has referred you, mentioning this connection can significantly increase your chances of getting an interview.

Template Structure:

  • Opening: Immediately mention your referral: "[Name], who works in [department] at [Company], suggested I apply for this position."
  • Connection: Briefly explain your relationship with the referrer and why they recommended you.
  • Qualifications: Outline your relevant skills and experience for the position.
  • Company Knowledge: Demonstrate your understanding of the company, possibly informed by your referral.
  • Closing: Express appreciation for the consideration and reference your referral again.

5. Return to Workforce Cover Letter

If you've taken time away from your career, your cover letter should address the gap while emphasizing your relevant skills and eagerness to return.

Template Structure:

  • Opening: Express enthusiasm for the position and briefly acknowledge your career break.
  • Previous Experience: Highlight your relevant work experience before your break.
  • During the Break: Mention any relevant skills maintained or developed during your time away (courses, volunteer work, etc.).
  • Current Skills: Emphasize that your skills are up-to-date and relevant to the position.
  • Closing: Express enthusiasm for returning to the workforce and contributing to the company.

Tips for Using These Templates

While these templates provide a structure, remember to:

  • Customize each letter for the specific job and company
  • Include specific examples and achievements
  • Keep your letter concise (one page maximum)
  • Use the job description to identify key skills and requirements
  • Maintain a professional tone while letting your personality show
  • Proofread carefully before submitting

By tailoring your cover letter to your specific career situation, you'll create a more compelling case for why you're the right person for the job, even if your path hasn't been traditional.

fields.title: Cover Letter Do's and Don'ts: Expert Advice
fields.summary: Learn the essential do's and don'ts of cover letter writing from hiring experts to avoid common mistakes and create a compelling letter.
fields.content:
We've consulted with hiring managers and career experts to compile this comprehensive list of cover letter do's and don'ts. Follow these guidelines to create a cover letter that stands out for all the right reasons.

Cover Letter Do's

Do: Research the Company

Before writing your cover letter, thoroughly research the company. Understand their mission, values, products/services, and recent news. This knowledge allows you to tailor your letter to show how your skills and values align with the company's needs and culture.

Do: Address a Specific Person

Whenever possible, address your cover letter to the hiring manager by name. This shows initiative and attention to detail. If the name isn't in the job posting, check the company website, LinkedIn, or call the company to ask.

Do: Customize Each Letter

Tailor each cover letter to the specific job and company. Reference the job description and use similar language to show that you understand what they're looking for. Generic cover letters are easily spotted and often immediately discarded.

Do: Focus on What You Can Offer

Emphasize what you can contribute to the company, not what you hope to gain from the position. Show how your skills and experience will help solve their problems or meet their needs.

Do: Include Specific Examples

Support your claims with concrete examples of your achievements. Instead of saying you're "detail-oriented," describe a project where your attention to detail led to a positive outcome. Use numbers and metrics when possible.

Do: Show Enthusiasm

Express genuine interest in the position and company. Enthusiasm can set you apart from equally qualified candidates who seem less passionate about the opportunity.

Do: Keep It Concise

Limit your cover letter to one page with 3-4 paragraphs. Hiring managers often review many applications, so being clear and concise increases the chances your letter will be read completely.

Do: Proofread Carefully

Errors in your cover letter can immediately disqualify you. Proofread multiple times, use spell check, and ask someone else to review your letter before submitting.

Cover Letter Don'ts

Don't: Use a Generic Template

Avoid using the same cover letter for every application. Generic letters show a lack of effort and interest in the specific position.

Don't: Rehash Your Resume

Your cover letter should complement your resume, not repeat it. Use this opportunity to expand on key experiences, explain gaps, or highlight specific achievements relevant to the position.

Don't: Focus on Salary or Benefits

Avoid mentioning salary requirements or benefits unless specifically requested. Discussing compensation too early in the process can make you seem more interested in what you can get than what you can offer.

Don't: Use Clich√©s or Buzzwords

Phrases like "team player" or "think outside the box" have lost their impact through overuse. Instead, provide specific examples that demonstrate these qualities.

Don't: Include Irrelevant Information

Omit details that don't relate to the job requirements. Personal information like age, marital status, or religious affiliations should not be included.

Don't: Be Negative

Avoid criticizing previous employers or explaining why you left a job in negative terms. Focus on positive reasons for seeking new opportunities.

Don't: Exaggerate or Lie

Be honest about your qualifications and experience. Exaggerations or falsehoods can be discovered during background checks or interviews, damaging your credibility.

Don't: Use Overly Formal Language

While maintaining professionalism, avoid archaic or overly formal language that sounds unnatural. Your cover letter should reflect how you would communicate in a professional setting.

Expert Tips from Hiring Managers

We asked hiring managers what makes a cover letter stand out. Here's what they said:

"I look for cover letters that show the candidate has done their homework about our company and can articulate why they're a good fit for both the position and our culture." - Marketing Director
"The best cover letters tell me a story that I can't get from the resume. I want to understand the 'why' behind the candidate's interest in the role and how their experience has prepared them for it." - HR Manager
"I appreciate when candidates address potential concerns upfront, like employment gaps or career changes. It shows self-awareness and confidence." - Tech Recruiter

Final Thoughts

Your cover letter is often your first impression with a potential employer. By following these do's and don'ts, you'll create a compelling letter that showcases your qualifications and personality in the best possible light.

Remember that the ultimate goal of your cover letter is to secure an interview. Focus on making a strong case for why you deserve that opportunity, and you'll increase your chances of moving to the next stage in the hiring process.

fields.title: Tailor Each Cover Letter
fields.content: Customize your cover letter for each job application. Research the company and position to highlight relevant skills and experiences that match the job requirements.

fields.title: Address the Hiring Manager
fields.content: Whenever possible, address your cover letter to a specific person rather than using "To Whom It May Concern." Research the company website or call to find the hiring manager's name.

fields.title: Keep It Concise
fields.content: Limit your cover letter to one page with 3-4 paragraphs. Be clear and concise, focusing on your most relevant qualifications and achievements for the position.

fields.title: Highlight Achievements
fields.content: Don't just list job duties. Showcase specific accomplishments with measurable results that demonstrate your value. Use numbers and percentages when possible.

fields.title: Proofread Carefully
fields.content: Errors can immediately disqualify you. Proofread multiple times, use spell check, and ask someone else to review your cover letter before submitting.

fields.title: End With a Call to Action
fields.content: Conclude with a strong closing paragraph that expresses your interest in an interview and provides your contact information. Be confident but not presumptuous.
